name: imidodicarbonimidic diamide, n-(4-chlorophenyl)-
Reason: 1,3-diaminopropane has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison will be 1,3-diaminopropane, which has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a 4-chlorophenyl group. Phenyl groups, when connected to a diamine, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of imidodicarbonimidic diamide, we have one additional phenyl group linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
